tooltips.region: Geographic areas where climate change/sea level rise vulnerability studies have been conducted.
tooltips.hazard: Spatial extent for different coastal hazards that may affect coastal assets.  Impact zones were estimated across multiple planning horizons.
tooltips.climate: Future planning horizons representing the impact of climate change.
tooltips.scenario: Sea level rise scenarios (low, medium, and high) based on the regional sea level rise amounts.

tooltips.scenario:
Sea level rise scenarios (low, intermediate, high, and extreme) based on regional sea level rise amounts. Below is a table showing the scenario projections of relative sea level rise at Toke Point, Washington (NOAA 2017):

Scenario203020502100
Low4 cm (1.6 in)8 cm (3.1 in)19 cm (7.5 in)
Inter11 cm (4.3 in)25 cm (9.8 in)83 cm (32.7 in)
High22 cm (8.7 in)59 cm (23.2 in)229 cm (90.2 in)
Extr27 cm (10.6 in)73 cm (28.7 in)289 cm (113.8 in)

options.name: Sea Level Rise
options.description: Historical sea level trends are available from NOAA tide stations at Toke Point.

tooltips.region: Geographic areas where climate change/sea level rise vulnerability studies have been conducted.
tooltips.hazard: Spatial extent for different coastal hazards that may affect coastal assets.  Impact zones were estimated across multiple planning horizons.
tooltips.climate: Flood depths and extents are derived by calculating where excess stream flow ends up on the landscape. The Historic flood depths are based on an analysis of more than a century of past flood events. The Future flood depths are based on changes in temperature and precipitation relative to 1970-1999. The 2040s flood depth reference period is 2030-2059 and the 2080s flood depth reference period is 2070-2099.
tooltips.togglegroup_floodtype: The timing and magnitude of climate change will depend on the amount of greenhouse gases emitted and the response of the climate system to the change in greenhouse gases. There is considerable uncertainty about climate change because future greenhouse gas emissions are unknown and because different climate models predict different responses to certain greenhouse gas concentrations. Consequently we have included low and high scenarios to bracket the range of these two uncertainties, ranging from a low greenhouse gas emissions scenario and relatively smaller change in flooding, to a medium greenhouse gas scenario and relatively larger change in flooding.
tooltips.togglegroup_eventtype: Flooding events are defined by the probability that an equal or greater event will occur in a given year...sometimes referred to as the Annual Chance of Exceedance. The 100-year flood event is associated with conditions that have a 1% probability of occurring in any given year. Similarly, the 10-year flood is associated with conditions that have a 10% chance of occurring in any given year.
